add.note: Constructed the highly complex 8-speed sequential gearbox and the V12 engine block. Focused on ensuring the gear timing was perfect before sealing the chassis.
Assembled the front and rear suspension systems, including the shock absorbers and the structural linkage that connects the engine cradle to the mid-section.
Completed the main structural skeleton of the car. This stage involved merging the previous sub-assemblies into a single, rigid 1:8 scale chassis.
Built the steering mechanism and the front-end bodywork. Added the headlights and the intricate aerodynamic curves of the front fenders.
Assembled the massive rear engine cover. This stage featured the iconic horizontal slats that define the SP3's aesthetic and the hinge mechanisms for opening the hood.
Installed the interior cabin details, including the blue seats, and built the complex butterfly door mechanisms that allow the doors to open upward smoothly.
Finalized the build by completing the rear diffuser, tail lights, and attaching the unique silver-lacquered rims and tires to finish the model.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Started the foundation. Bag 1 builds the massive Technic core frame. It's the most critical part to ensure the ship doesn't sag under its own weight later.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Installed the seven heavy-duty landing legs. Getting the internal pins aligned was a bit tedious but essential for stability.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Interior work. Built the main hold featuring the Dejarik (holochess) table and the engineering station. Includes Chewbacca and C-3PO.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Completed the rear compartment interior detailing and the hyperdrive unit. Added the Han Solo and Princess Leia minifigures.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Constructed the rear underside hull and the iconic blue light-up engine thrusters using transparent light-blue tubes.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Built the internal framework for the two front mandibles. The greebling (mechanical detailing) starts to get very dense here.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Focused on the underside mandible plating. These sections use clever Technic pin connections to stay secure while inverted.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Assembled the top mandible panels. These are mostly plate-heavy and include the circular maintenance access bays.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Constructed the bottom quad-laser cannon and the functional boarding ramp mechanism.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Finished the top central hull panels and the rear-top plating. Added Finn and BB-8 to the crew.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Added the final large hull sections to the rear. The ship’s iconic silhouette is now almost entirely enclosed.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Built the complex circular docking ports for both the port and starboard sides.

tasks.title: LEGO® Star Wars™ Millennium Falcon (75192) | 7,541 Pieces

add.note: Final build day. Assembled the cockpit, the access tunnel, and the interchangeable sensor dishes. Build complete!.
Finally cracking open Box 1! The scale of the base plates is already intimidating, but I'm so hyped to see this come together.
Finished the Bow! The way the hull tapers using those hinge bricks is actually genius engineering. It looks so sleek sitting on the table.
The tiny boiler builds are actually adorable. It's crazy that most of this detail gets hidden once the decks go on, but I'm glad I know they're inside.
Starting the Grand Staircase. The repetition is setting in. My thumbs are actually starting to throb from all these tiny 1x1 plates.
Finally finished the first third of the ship. Standing the bow up next to the midsection... wow. This is going to be absolutely massive.
I am so sick of white windows. Seriously. If I see another window frame I might scream. The repetition in this section is brutal.
THE STERN IS A NIGHTMARE. Getting the angle of the hull to line up with the Technic pins is making me want to throw this whole box out the window. Why is this so difficult!?
Okay, the stern curve is finished. I'm exhausted and my dining table is completely buried in Lego. I need a break.
Building the reciprocating engines was actually therapeutic. Seeing the pistons move when you turn the turbines is the coolest thing I've ever seen in a Lego set.
Done. 9,090 pieces later. Connecting the three massive sections was terrifying but so rewarding. It's a masterpiece. Now... where do I put it?

James Clear shares his personal journey of recovering from a devastating high school baseball injury. He explains how small, daily habits were the key to regaining his strength and eventually achieving academic and athletic success, setting the stage for the 'atomic' philosophy.

tasks.title: Chapter 1 – The Surprising Power of Atomic Habits

add.note: This chapter introduces the concept of 'marginal gains'—the idea that getting 1% better every day results in huge long-term shifts. Clear argues that habits are the compound interest of self-improvement and that you should focus on systems rather than goals.

tasks.title: Chapter 2 – How Your Habits Shape Your Identity (and Vice Versa)

add.note: Clear discusses the three levels of behavior change: outcomes, processes, and identity. He argues that the most effective way to change your habits is to focus not on what you want to achieve, but on who you wish to become, as identity-based habits are more sustainable.

tasks.title: Chapter 3 – How to Build Better Habits in 4 Simple Steps

add.note: Introduces the Four Steps of the Habit Loop: Cue, Craving, Response, and Reward. This framework explains how the brain builds habits and provides the foundation for the Four Laws of Behavior Change that the rest of the book explores.

tasks.title: Chapter 4 – The Man Who Didn’t Look Right

add.note: Focuses on the 1st Law: Make It Obvious. Clear discusses the 'Habits Scorecard' to build awareness of current behaviors and 'Pointing-and-Calling' to raise the level of awareness from a non-conscious habit to a conscious one.

tasks.title: Chapter 5 – The Best Way to Start a New Habit

add.note: Explains 'implementation intentions' and 'habit stacking.' By using the formula 'I will [BEHAVIOR] at [TIME] in [LOCATION]' or pairing a new habit with an old one, you create a clear plan that removes the need for motivation or willpower.

tasks.title: Chapter 6 – Motivation Is Overrated; Environment Often Matters More

add.note: Discusses 'choice architecture' and how our environment shapes our behavior. By making the cues for good habits more visible and the cues for bad habits invisible, you can design your surroundings to make better choices easier.

Clear reveals that 'disciplined' people aren't necessarily stronger; they just design environments that don't require willpower. The secret to self-control is making the cues of your bad habits invisible rather than trying to resist them.

tasks.title: Chapter 8 – How to Make a Habit Irresistible

add.note: Introduces the 2nd Law: Make It Attractive. Using the concept of 'temptation bundling,' Clear explains how to link an action you want to do with an action you need to do, leveraging dopamine to make habits more enticing.

tasks.title: Chapter 9 – The Role of Family and Friends in Shaping Your Habits

add.note: We tend to adopt the habits of the people around us. This chapter explores how to join cultures where your desired behavior is the normal behavior, leveraging our biological drive to fit in with the close, the many, and the powerful.

tasks.title: Chapter 10 – How to Find and Fix the Causes of Your Bad Habits

add.note: Explains how to reframe your mindset to make bad habits unattractive. By highlighting the benefits of avoiding a bad habit rather than the 'sacrifice' of giving it up, you can shift the underlying craving that drives the behavior.

tasks.title: Chapter 11 – Walk Slowly, but Never Backward

add.note: Introduces the 3rd Law: Make It Easy. Clear distinguishes between 'being in motion' (planning/strategizing) and 'taking action' (performing the habit). He emphasizes that repetition, not perfection, is the key to habit formation.

tasks.title: Chapter 12 – The Law of Least Effort

add.note: Human behavior follows the path of least resistance. Clear suggests reducing the friction associated with good behaviors (priming the environment) and increasing the friction for bad behaviors to make them harder to perform.

tasks.title: Chapter 13 – How to Stop Procrastinating by Using the Two-Minute Rule

add.note: The Two-Minute Rule states: 'When you start a new habit, it should take less than two minutes to do.' This helps you overcome procrastination by focusing on 'the art of showing up' rather than the difficulty of the entire task.

tasks.title: Chapter 14 – How to Make Good Habits Inevitable and Bad Habits Impossible

add.note: Focuses on 'commitment devices'—choices you make in the present that lock in better behavior in the future. Automation through technology and one-time choices can ensure good habits happen automatically.

tasks.title: Chapter 15 – The Cardinal Rule of Behavior Change

add.note: Introduces the 4th Law: Make It Satisfying. While the first three laws increase the odds of doing it this time, the fourth law increases the odds of doing it next time. We repeat behaviors that are immediately rewarded.

tasks.title: Chapter 16 – How to Stick with Good Habits Every Day

add.note: Discusses habit tracking and the 'don't break the chain' strategy. Visual progress provides immediate satisfaction and motivation. Clear also shares the 'never miss twice' rule to help you recover quickly when life gets in the way.

tasks.title: Chapter 17 – How an Accountability Partner Can Change Everything

add.note: Explores the inverse of the 4th Law: Make It Unsatisfying. An accountability partner or a habit contract creates an immediate social cost for failure, making the pain of not doing the habit greater than the effort of doing it.

tasks.title: Chapter 18 – The Truth About Talent (When Genes Matter and When They Don’t)

add.note: Clear explains how to pick the right 'game' to play. While genes don't eliminate the need for hard work, they clarify it. You should build habits that align with your natural strengths to make success more likely.

tasks.title: Chapter 19 – The Goldilocks Rule: How to Stay Motivated in Life and Work

add.note: The Goldilocks Rule states that humans experience peak motivation when working on tasks that are right on the edge of their current abilities—not too hard, not too easy. This is how to manage boredom and stay engaged long-term.

tasks.title: Chapter 20 – The Downside of Creating Good Habits

add.note: Habits can lead to complacency. Once a skill is automatic, we stop paying attention to small errors. Clear emphasizes 'Reflection and Review' to maintain mastery and ensure your habits continue to serve your goals as you evolve.

tasks.title: Conclusion: The Secret to Results That Last

add.note: The final summary reinforces that success is not a goal to reach, but a system to improve. Small, atomic habits, when layered upon one another, create a powerful foundation for lasting change and continuous growth.
After the downfall of the dark wizard Voldemort, baby Harry Potter is left on the doorstep of his Muggle relatives, the Dursleys, by Dumbledore, McGonagall, and Hagrid.
Ten years later, Harry is treated poorly by the Dursleys. During a trip to the zoo for Dudley's birthday, Harry accidentally makes the glass of a boa constrictor's tank disappear.

tasks.title: Chapter 3 – The Letters from No One

add.note: Mysterious letters addressed to Harry begin arriving. Uncle Vernon goes to extreme lengths to prevent Harry from reading them, eventually moving the family to a remote shack on a rock.

tasks.title: Chapter 4 – The Keeper of the Keys

add.note: Hagrid arrives at the shack to personally deliver Harry's invitation to Hogwarts. He reveals that Harry is a wizard and explains the truth about how his parents really died.
Hagrid takes Harry to Diagon Alley to shop for school supplies. Harry visits Gringotts Bank, meets Ollivander to get his wand, and begins to realize his fame in the wizarding world.

tasks.title: Chapter 6 – The Journey from Platform Nine and Three-Quarters

add.note: Harry boards the Hogwarts Express at King's Cross. He meets Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger and has his first encounter with Draco Malfoy while traveling to the castle.
The first-year students arrive at Hogwarts and are sorted into their houses by a magical hat. Harry, Ron, and Hermione are all sorted into Gryffindor.
Classes begin, and Harry finds that Professor Snape seems to have a deep, inexplicable dislike for him. Harry also learns about a break-in at Gringotts that happened on his birthday.
A flying lesson leads to a confrontation with Malfoy. Later, while trying to meet Malfoy for a duel, the trio accidentally discovers a giant three-headed dog guarding a trapdoor.
A mountain troll is let into the school on Halloween. Harry and Ron save Hermione from the troll in the girls' bathroom, and the three officially become best friends.
Harry plays his first professional Quidditch match. Despite someone jinxing his broom, he manages to catch the Golden Snitch in his mouth to win the game for Gryffindor.
Harry discovers a magical mirror that shows the viewer's deepest desire. He spends nights staring at his deceased parents until Dumbledore explains the danger of the mirror.
The trio finally identifies Nicolas Flamel as the creator of the Sorcerer's Stone. Harry suspects Snape is trying to steal the stone for himself after another tense Quidditch match.
Hagrid wins a dragon egg and hatches it in his hut. The trio helps smuggle the dragon, Norbert, to Ron's brother in Romania, but they are caught by Filch after the handoff.
For detention, Harry, Hermione, Neville, and Malfoy enter the Forbidden Forest with Hagrid. Harry encounters a hooded figure drinking unicorn blood and is rescued by a centaur.
Thinking Snape is about to steal the stone, the trio goes through the trapdoor. They overcome trials involving Devil's Snare, flying keys, and a giant game of wizard's chess.

tasks.title: Chapter 17 – The Man with Two Faces

add.note: Harry discovers Professor Quirrell, not Snape, is the thief. Harry faces Voldemort (living on Quirrell's head) and secures the stone. Gryffindor wins the House Cup at the end-of-year feast.
